ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about applied methods in labor econ. I could improve my previous knowledge and extend it to new methods and models both empirically and theoretically, whereby there was a slight focus on the empirical methods. I liked the selection of topics, going beyond the usual labor topics of taxation, labor supply, and education.
Topics covered in labour economics, methods used in advanced structural estimation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: - Reading group: It really helped to read papers on the various topics which highlighted different aspects than the ones discussed in class - Knowledgeable professor: Always pointed out the strengths and weaknesses of papers which helped to assess what can be done and what is beyond the paper - Reasonable overview of various topics Weaknesses: - Should impose more structure on discussing the theoretical and empirical derivations. Discussion of results should not take up that much time - Maybe proceed at a slower pace. Sometimes it was a little bit too fast - End on time
This course could be improved by ensuring the common objective among topics and outlining a structure in which the literature has evolved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes at it is a reasonable course for learning the up-to-date methods in research even if you are not interested in labor econ. If you are interested in labor econ, obviously you have to take the class! Costas is a brilliant instructor and he puts forth a lot of effort to teach this course which can be seen in his slides and his engagement in class.
Especially if someone is interested in structural estimation.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is a well-balanced course, covering theoretical models, econometric tools and applied topics. Summing up, it is a very complete course.
